item.title: Launching Mentorships! by Alex Beddows
item.content:encoded:
I am proud and happy to announce I am launching mentorships via the DiNusty Empire. 

I am supplying 2 types of mentorships, Environment Art and Career Coaching.


 

In this mentorship, you will be guided through creating environment or material art through a pragmatic and deliberate mindset while understanding just what is required from the mentee to reach their next goal.

This includes understanding just what is expected within the AAA games industry in addition to making sure you have a fully equipped skill set to aid you in pursuing your dream role within the games industry.

The mentorship can be as broad or focused as the mentee needs, whether it is learning a particular workflow in Substance Designer to working out the pipeline and techniques to push their project to the next level.

⬤ Environment Art Pipelines ⬤ Prop Art ⬤ Material Authoring ⬤ UE4 Workflows ⬤ Shader Art ⬤


 

In this mentorship, we will focus on the interpersonal skills you can improve to aid in your career aside from just making art. So much focus being placed on hard skills it is very easy to undervalue and ignore your soft skills, which quite often is what holds them back from progressing.

The skills range from preparing for your first steps into the games industry with Interview prep, CV improvements and having a presentable portfolio, all the way to negotiating promotions while not burning bridges or making sure your online persona speaks to what kind of artist you want to be.

⬤ Interview Prep ⬤ CV Improvement ⬤ Portfolio Organisation to Maximise Hiring ⬤ Brand Development ⬤

item.description:
I wanted to take an idea from traditional painting, Master studies and apply it to material art, take one of my favourite materials made by Dannie Carlone and try to recreate it in Substance Designer using Megascans for the Leaves.

item.title: Growth Via Community - 3 Years Of Development by Alex Beddows
item.content:encoded:
This year I asked Jeremy to do my third portfolio review, and looking back this is surreal, I look back to 3 years ago, where I was as an artist and as a person: 

  • Unhappy with my career
  • Hating my own art
  • Not seeing any development 
  • On the verge of quitting art altogether

Then I stumble upon the DiNusty youtube channel & community, and I owe my development to that community, they supported and aided my growth and I am forever grateful for it, people ask why I am so invested in producing the podcast or any other learning content, and the answer is if I can help someone like this community helped...me then it is 100% worth it. 

November 2017

August 2018

July 2020

item.title: Zbrush > SD Stone Wall by Alex Beddows
item.description:
I got reminded just how good zbrush materials can look after Dannie Carlone posted on twitter about them. So decided to try my hand at one again, it did highlight one glaring issue... my 'traditional' 3d skills are very rusty. But this whole process was very therapeutic and I definitely want to do more of these in the future!

https://www.artstation.com/danniecarlone

item.description: Alex Beddows host of the Game Dev Podcast and Senior Environment Artist at Counterplay Games joins us to talk about his path into the industry, how the industry is changing, what an environment artist does and why the Game Dev Discussion Podcast is important.
item.content:encoded:
Alex Beddows host of the Game Dev Podcast and Senior Environment Artist at Counterplay Games joins us to talk about his path into the industry, how the industry is changing, what an environment artist does and why the Game Dev Discussion Podcast is important.

View this on ArtStation
Alex Beddows on ArtStation

item.title: The Role Of Education In The Games Industry by Alex Beddows
item.content:encoded:
It's the last one I swear, I had so much canceled this year I guess I'm making up for lost time. But this is one close to my heart but I'll be delivering a talk on 'The Role Of Education In The Games Industry.'


I have to confess to being a self-taught artist, I didn't go into higher education, from College straight into my first studio job. Though this is not to discount higher education, I will get into what role it plays along with the wider online tools and communities that forge the modern game dev education pipeline.


 October 18th - 23rd. https://viewconference.it

item.title: The Value An Artist Brings To A Business by Alex Beddows
item.content:encoded:
One of the other talks I will be doing at View Conference 'The Value An Artist Brings To A Business'. 

I speak to a ton of artist through podcasts, mentoring or talking to peers, one thing that is consistent across the CG industry is there is a finite amount of jobs compared to the number of people wanting to work in these fields. We wrap our identity in being an artist and creating art, however, we are for more than that, we are at the peak of creativity and these mindsets and ways of thinking drives innovation in business.  


The conference is on October 18th - 23rd. More info at:

https://viewconference.it

item.title: Understanding The Limitations of Substance Designer by Alex Beddows
item.content:encoded:
One of the other talks I will be doing View Conference 'Understanding The Limitations of Substance Designer'. 

I have been knee-deep in Designer for the past couple of years, making a variety of materials for AAA and personal development. These 2 things need clarifying, if you look at some of the huge names in the material art community and see the 100% Designer materials on their ArtStation, this leads to young artists observing and creating a ton of materials that look cool but have 0 utility in production, In this talk, I delve into the differences and how leveraging other software will level up your Material quality!  


The conference is on October 18th - 23rd. More info at:

https://viewconference.it

item.title: The value of self-awareness - View Conference by Alex Beddows
item.content:encoded:
In October I will be attending View Conference in Italy and delivering a series of talks. One of which being 'The Value Of Self-Awareness'. 

With this talk I get into how self-awareness can impact and accelerate your development, this affects everything from who you associate with, how you spend your time, and your ability as an artist. Knowing these things will allow you to be deliberate in what you do on your development as an artist and as a person. 


The conference is on October 18th - 23rd. More info at:

https://www.viewconference.it/

item.title: Halo 3 - Crows Nest - Reinforced Concrete Wall by Alex Beddows
item.description:
I have recently replayed Halo 3 since it released on PC, and saw a bunch of materials that I thought would make fun studies, so here is my first from the mission crows nest.

I also used this study as a chance to try out and experiment with new ways to create some of the fundamentals in Designer such as cracks, edge wear, and paint peeling.

100% SD

item.title: Game Dev Discussion Episode 55 : Nicolas Wirrrmann by Alex Beddows
item.content:encoded:
We have a special guest this week, Nicolas Wirrmann, the product manager for Substance Designer at Adobe. We dug into how Substance grew over the years and how they first started getting implemented into AAA games. We also got into the game changing nodes were in Designer and how UE5 will effect the material pipeline.

.

Listen on Spotify ⯈ https://open.spotify.com/show/7spDMpMZJ9dr3Ziu8bRwCA

Listen on SoundCloud ⯈ https://soundcloud.com/gamedevdiscussion

Listen on iTunes ⯈ https://podcasts.apple.com/gb/podcast/game-dev-discussion/id1459400002

Listen on YouTube ⯈ https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCKfTBvcsO9Kw0b5EVuf4CJQ

item.title: Game Art Podcast by Alex Beddows
item.content:encoded:
I had the pleasure of going on the Game Art Talk podcast, it was fun being on the other side of the mic, and Chris was a fantastic host.

We got into :

  • How to build genuine relationships rather than just 'networking'

  • My unconventional pathway into the industry as a self-taught artist

  • Takeaways and learnings from my time as a lead at Dekogon

  • How running the podcast has affected me and my career

  • General thoughts on how to maximize your chances of breaking into the industry

item.title: Game Dev Discussion Episode 54: Mike Pickton by Alex Beddows
item.content:encoded:
We have our first tech artist...and he is a Lead! Mike Pickton from Playground Games shed some light on the role of tech and why he got into it, some issues surrounding the lack of knowledge in the public space about the field while point out mistakes he sees from artists that come up a lot!

.

.

item.title: Blender Simulated space pad material by Alex Beddows
item.description:
I have always loved using marvelous designer in my materials and after Lukas Stratmann made a tutorial on using blender to simulate cloth I thought I would give it a try. It was also a chance to try out the PBR render node, so now all renders were captured in Designer and UE4.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6pMss8n36w8&t=350s

item.title: Game Dev Discussion Episode 53 : Josh Lynch by Alex Beddows
item.content:encoded:
Josh has got the hatrick! This is an important episode of the podcast, we talk about the problems in the way game art careers are structured that means that 10 year mark artists can stall out, seniors feeling pressured to jump into lead roles even though they have no desire to be a manager and the We vs ME mentality!

.
Josh’s ArtStation ⯈ https://www.artstation.com/joshlynch#5347

.

item.content:encoded:
This debut episode of a new series sees me, Jay Cummings, Michael Kinsey, Kieran Goodson and Patrick Ziegler react and unpack the recent UE5 announcement while trying to work out the impact it will have on the industry.

item.title: Game Dev Discussion Episode 52: Michael Kinsey by Alex Beddows
item.content:encoded:
This week we sat down with the newest DiNusty Partner, Michael Kinsey. We got stuck into why we thought Blender blew up with 2.8, what leads to someone needing to work through burnout and whether or not your quality as an artist is only as good as your portfolio!

.

item.title: Game Dev Discussion Episode 51: James Ritossa & Rogelio Olguin by Alex Beddows
item.content:encoded:
This week we have returning guests and material guru's, James and Rogelio,  We talked about the future of material art and what effects machine learning will have on the job, Rights we have as artists and some of the issues around blender and tool providers.

.

item.title: New Job / Life Update by Alex Beddows
item.content:encoded:
So for those who do not know, I will be starting a new role as a Senior Environment Artist at Counterplay Games. People who know me know I am not a very emotional person, however, when I got a flood of supportive messages I did choke up a little! Not sure why it was overwhelming at the time...I think seeing people get in touch who have played a part in my development and growth over the past few years was humbling. That in combination with a euphoric moment of 'I made it' is what I think caught me off guard.

Although I have worked on many great projects with so many incredible artist's, Counterplay and in extension Godfall is a dream project for me, it is an art style I am passionate about while working with a team of artists I have spent the past few years looking up to, folks like Tim Simpson and Enrico Tammekänd who have aided in my development since day one of me taking this game art career seriously. 

  I have had quite a few questions and what's going on with other things so to clarify...YES, I am still working for ArtStation in the exact same capacity as before.

Dekogon I have stepped down as Lead Artist to enable me to pursue other opportunities, I owe a massive thank you to Clinton Crumpler, he gave me this great opportunity and through it, I have made some of my closest friends, the culture and company he has built is something special and I count my blessings to have been a small part of it!

Lastly, I owe most of my development to this amazing guy! What Jeremy has created and fostered with the DiNsuty Learning community is special. It is where most of my development took place, where I met most of my friends and it all came from this 1 guy wanting to help others learn is incredible....thank you for the amazing work you and the team do to make it the amazing community that it is!

item.title: Mayterial | Nature | Forest Ground Roots by Alex Beddows
item.description: For Mayterial I wanted to learn something and try something new, I have never been a fan of making scatter assets in SD, it always felt like an awkward compromise sO I tried using Megscans atlas's for the scatter items (leaves). This felt very natural and worked far better than I expected, a big thank you to Ben Wilson for opening my eyes and helping figure this workflow out !
item.content:encoded:
For Mayterial I wanted to learn something and try something new, I have never been a fan of making scatter assets in SD, it always felt like an awkward compromise sO I tried using Megscans atlas's for the scatter items (leaves). This felt very natural and worked far better than I expected, a big thank you to Ben Wilson for opening my eyes and helping figure this workflow out !

View this on ArtStation
Alex Beddows on ArtStation

item.title: Game Dev Discussion Episode 50: Doru Bogdan by Alex Beddows
item.content:encoded:
We are at the half century mark, episode 50 is with an artist I am a big admirer of and the coalition Nodevember winner Doru Bogdan. We got into how he fell in love with Substance Designer, the struggles job rejections and how he found parallels between Zbrush and Designer!

.

item.title: Antelope Canyon Sand by Alex Beddows
item.description: I have been creating a lot of large macro detail materials so switching gears into a material that is very micro detail heavy. I am planning to use this with my sandstone material to create a little composition for antelope canyon.
item.content:encoded:
I have been creating a lot of large macro detail materials so switching gears into a material that is very micro detail heavy. I am planning to use this with my sandstone material to create a little composition for antelope canyon.
